claim: In the EU, most people are not Muslim in any country.

supporting.text: According to demographic data from Eurostat, the majority of the population in all EU member states identifies as Christian or non-religious.

attacks.text: According to demographic data from Eurostat, the majority of the population in all EU member states identifies as Christian or non-religious.
Some EU countries, such as Bulgaria and Cyprus, have significant Muslim minorities that may approach or exceed 10% of the population, which challenges the notion of 'most people' being non-Muslim.
Even in countries with significant Muslim minorities, the majority of the population still identifies as Christian or non-religious, maintaining the original claim's validity.
The claim does not account for undocumented immigrants or unregistered residents who may be Muslim and not reflected in official statistics.
Official demographic data from Eurostat is the most reliable source available, and while some undercounting may occur, it is unlikely to significantly alter the overall religious composition.

supporting.text: Pew Research Center studies show that Muslims constitute less than 10% of the population in every EU country as of 2025.

attacks.text: Pew Research Center studies show that Muslims constitute less than 10% of the population in every EU country as of 2025.
Pew Research Center's methodology may undercount undocumented Muslim immigrants, who are less likely to participate in surveys.
Government census data in major EU countries aligns with Pew's estimates, validating their methodology.
Localized urban areas in some EU countries (e.g., Marseille, France) have Muslim populations exceeding 20%, contradicting the national average claim.
City-level exceptions do not refute country-wide statistics, which remain below 10% even when accounting for urban concentrations.

supporting.text: National census data across EU countries consistently reports that Islam is not the majority religion in any member state.

attacks.text: National census data across EU countries consistently reports that Islam is not the majority religion in any member state.

Some EU countries, such as Bulgaria and Cyprus, have significant Muslim minorities that approach or exceed 10% of the population, which may challenge the perception of 'most people not being Muslim' in certain regions.
Even in countries with significant Muslim minorities, census data still shows that Islam is not the majority religion, supporting the original claim.
Census data may undercount Muslim populations due to undocumented migrants or reluctance to report religion in secular societies.
Official census methodologies in the EU are designed to ensure accuracy and inclusivity, making significant undercounting unlikely.

supporting.text: EU-wide surveys on religious affiliation indicate that no country has a Muslim population exceeding 50% of its total inhabitants.

attacks.text: EU-wide surveys on religious affiliation indicate that no country has a Muslim population exceeding 50% of its total inhabitants.
Some EU countries, such as Cyprus, have Muslim populations that are close to 50% when considering unrecognized territories like Northern Cyprus.
Official EU statistics typically exclude unrecognized territories, so Northern Cyprus's Muslim population is not counted in EU-wide surveys.
Local surveys in certain regions, like Molenbeek in Belgium, show Muslim majorities, which could imply higher concentrations not reflected in national averages.
Municipal or neighborhood-level majorities do not equate to national majorities, and such cases are exceptions rather than the norm.
